commander.name: Generale di Brigata Enrico Frattini
commander.previous_service: Parachute forces commander, veteran of East Africa

command.headquarters_location: Deir el Munassib sector, El Alamein line

47/32 M35 Cannon.notes: Air-droppable, breaks into 6 parts for pack transport

47/32 M35 AT Gun.notes: Same as field artillery, dual-purpose weapon

supply_status.notes: Desert supply situation critical; dependent on Axis supply lines across Mediterranean

subordinate_units.notes: Formerly 3rd Paratroopers Regiment; received II and IV from 185th Regiment
II Gruppo disbanded in North Africa; two groups of 8x 47/32 guns each
Former VIII Paratroopers Battalion/187th Regiment; specialized in demolitions and obstacles

tactical_doctrine.role: Elite airborne infantry employed as ground troops in defensive role
special_capabilities: Trained for airborne operations but used as elite infantry at El Alamein
Superior physical fitness and marksmanship training
Experienced in individual initiative and small-unit tactics
Equipped with higher proportion of automatic weapons than standard infantry
Trained in demolitions and obstacle clearance
tactical_innovations: Decentralized command structure allowing platoon/squad independence
Light, mobile organization suitable for rapid deployment
Use of 47/32 dual-purpose guns for both AT and infantry support
Integration of assault engineers at division level
Higher proportion of NCOs for decentralized leadership
known_issues: Lack of organic armor or heavy artillery
No motorized transport for tactical mobility
47/32 guns inadequate against British medium tanks
Division deployed at reduced strength (~5,200 vs. full establishment)
tactical_doctrine.desert_adaptations: Minimal - division arrived in North Africa mid-1942 with limited time to adapt; relied on elite training and morale rather than specialized desert equipment

special_rules: Stubborn Defense: +1 to defensive combat rolls
Elite Training: May reroll failed morale checks once per game
Light Infantry: +1 movement in rough terrain
Tank Hunters: Infantry AT attacks at +1 vs. light/medium tanks
Undersupplied: -1 to sustained combat beyond 6 turns
historical_engagements: Battle of El Alamein (23 October - 4 November 1942)
Defense of Deir el Munassib sector
Final stand at El Alamein (destroyed in place, November 1942)

historical_notes.formation: Formed 1 September 1941 in Tarquinia as 1st Paratroopers Division; renamed 185ª Divisione Paracadutisti Folgore on 27 July 1942
historical_notes.deployment: Arrived North Africa early August 1942; deployed to southern sector of El Alamein line at Deir el Munassib
historical_notes.combat_record: Fought with exceptional courage at El Alamein, holding sector against British Commonwealth forces including armor. Destroyed in place during final phase of battle, November 1942. Earned widespread recognition for tenacity despite being infantry vs. armor.
historical_notes.casualties: Division virtually annihilated at El Alamein; survivors captured. Approximately 4,500+ casualties/POWs from original 5,200 strength
historical_notes.reputation: Considered Italy's premier elite infantry formation; 'Folgore' (Lightning) name reflected airborne origin. Performance at El Alamein earned respect from Allied commanders, particularly for defense against armor with inadequate AT weapons.
historical_notes.reorganization: New Folgore division formed in Italy 1943 to replace unit destroyed in North Africa

source: TM E 30-420 Italian Military Forces (1943) - Parachute division organization
STORMO! Italian WWII Airborne Units by Vince Tassone - Folgore structure at El Alamein
Multiple web sources on Folgore at El Alamein (Comando Supremo, Military Wiki)
Axis History Forum discussions on Folgore organization and equipment
validation.validated_by: Claude Code Agent - Autonomous TO&E Extraction
known_gaps: Exact officer/NCO/enlisted breakdown estimated using Italian standard ratios
Individual battalion strength numbers estimated from division total
Commander names for subordinate units unknown except division commander
Exact vehicle inventory estimated based on Italian paratrooper TO&E patterns
Some equipment quantities calculated from standard Italian organization tables
validation.methodology: Division-level data from primary sources (TM E 30-420) and secondary sources (historical websites). Personnel distributed using Italian paratrooper organization patterns. Equipment allocated based on Italian infantry regiment tables adapted for paratrooper organization. Battalion strengths estimated from documented 7 battalion structure and ~5,200 total strength.
